title: 107_hr3808
content: The Act titled "Consistent Public Land Laws Enforcement Act of 2002" provides consistent enforcement authority for national park system lands, national forest lands, and other public lands. The Act "Consistent Public Land Laws Enforcement Act of 2002" amends regulations for lands under the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management and the National Park System Lands to enforce violations as misdemeanors with fines or imprisonment. The Act "Consistent Public Land Laws Enforcement Act of 2002" amends regulations for National Park System Lands to enforce violations as misdemeanors with fines or imprisonment. The Act "Consistent Public Land Laws Enforcement Act of 2002" amends regulations for National Park System Lands to enforce violations as misdemeanors with fines or imprisonment. It also includes amendments related to special management authorities and lease and permit authorities under the Secretary of the Interior. The Act enforces violations of regulations for National Park System Lands as misdemeanors, with fines or imprisonment as penalties. A person who knowingly and willfully violates a rule or regulation may be guilty of a Class A misdemeanor and subject to fines or imprisonment. SEC. 3. CONSISTENT AUTHORITIES REGARDING USE OF COLLECTED FINES. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to allow fines collected for violations of regulations to be used by the Secretary for land improvement, protection, rehabilitation, and increasing public awareness of regulations. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 is amended to allow fines collected for violations of regulations to be used by the Secretary for land improvement, protection, rehabilitation, and increasing public awareness. Excess funds will be returned to the treasury. Additionally, fines imposed under section 3571 of title 18, United States Code, will result in moneys being received by the United States for authorized use. The fines collected for violations of regulations can be used by the Secretary of the Interior for land improvement, protection, rehabilitation, and increasing public awareness. Excess funds will be returned to the treasury. The paragraph discusses the amendment to Section 7 of the Act of June 20, 1958 regarding the treatment of certain moneys received on behalf of the Forest Service, including fines imposed for violations of regulations. The amendment to Section 7 of the Act of June 20, 1958 allows the Secretary of Agriculture to use moneys received for improvement, protection, or rehabilitation work on National Forest System lands, as well as for increasing public awareness of rules and regulations. Excess funds are to be returned to the treasury. The amendment allows the Secretary of Agriculture to use funds for National Forest System lands and public awareness, with excess funds returned to the treasury.
